sp.p: Me, what to doe Sir.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Tis justice I present it to your feete, whose love Arm'd me to vindicate your honour.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: My honour?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: This is but the first of my valour in your cause; if you affect these monuments, I'le make you up an Armory: meane time receive my service with this sword; if hee provoake me to fight with him againe; I'le cut his hand off and bringe it with me, to present the next.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Whose hand deare Servant?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Hee is not worth the naminge, alas; this does not deserve your knowledge; only thinke what I dare doe, when your bright name is questioned: and I in time may merrit to bee call'd the darlinge of your Virgin thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sist
sp.p: Pray stay; my name traduc'd? who was so impudent? doe me the grace to let me know on whome your valour has bin exercis'd.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Why upon the formall thinge, call'd Courtwell, I would call him Gentleman, but that I have baffled him; you neede noe other witnesse then his sword: Shee shuts the doore .With the fine holliday hilt.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Looke you Sir I have made fast the doore because I meane before you goe, to have a satisfaction for the base Injury you have done me.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I done you Injury?

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p:
Not that I value Courtwell whome you would pretend has bin too saucy with my honour, but cause I scorne to owne a goodnesse should depend upon your sword or vindication: I'le fight with thee my selfe in this
smale volume against your bulke in folio.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Excellent wench.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I was your champion, Lady.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: I had rather have no fame then have thee name it; thou fight for a Ladyes honour, and disarme a Gentleman? thou fence before the Pageants & make roome for the porters, when like Elephants they carry once a yeare the Cyttie Castles: or goe a feastinge with the drum or schole boyes to the banke syde & save the beares a whippinge that day: come Sir I meane to have about with you.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: At what weapon?

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: This, and none other, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I'le rather bleede to death then lift a sworde in my defence▪ whose inconsiderate brightnesse may fright the roses from your Cheekes, & leave the lyllyes to Lament the rude divorce: but were a man to dare me, and your enemie, my rage more nimble then the Median shaft should flye into his bosome, and your eye change Anger into smiles, to see me fight and cut him into a ragged staffe.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I cannot hold no longer; you have got a stomack Sir with running, I'le try how you can eate a Sword.

sp.speaker: Dev
sp.p: Have you an ambush Lady; I'le cry out murther, tis two to one. Faire play!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Let me but cut one legg off to marre his running.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Hold: let me speake.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What canst thou saie for thy basenesse?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Some men love witt, and can without dishonour endure a Ieast; Why? doe you thinke I knew not you were heere & but observ'd to see my humour? I came to wayte upon you with your sword.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: How came you by it? Confesse before this Lady.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Doest thinke her witt's so lymber to beleive I could compell it from thee, twas a trick, a meere conceipt of mirth, thou shalt have myne: Doest thinke I stand upon a sword? I'le give thee a case of pistolls, when wee come to London; and shoote mee when I love thee not: pox on it, thou apprehendest me well enough.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: But I am not satisfied, doe you loue this Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Hum;

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You will resolve Sir.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: As may become a stranger; I will not lose thy friendshipp for all woman kinde.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Hee dares, not owne you.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: I easily forgive him: I should hate my selfe if I depended on his pitty.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Thou art a noble wench: shall wee leave of these Jiggs, and speake our minds in earnest by these twyn lipps, I loue thee extreamly.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Sweare by your owne.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: They shall bee myne: Monsieur, for your pennance you shall along & witnesse.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: What I pray.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: The priest shall tell you, come, wee have both dissembled, wee doe loue one an other.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Vnlesse you will denie me in the church. I have vowed to lye with you this night: Device, amble before, and finde the Parson out; wee will bee frends, and thou shalt bee her Father.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I must mayntayne my honour, or be beaten.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Com we'le have no more acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Very pretty! I may deceave you yet for all your confidence.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If the skye falle, wee'le have the darkes to supper. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lady Sir Francis and Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: It was a strange neglect, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I confesse it, and not deserve to live for it, yet if you but knew my sufferings.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Let her bee Judge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By no meanes Madame.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: You may trust her knowledge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: This is worse then a whippinge now, these Ladyes have no mercy on a delinquent; I must stand to it; there is no tyrant to a chambermayde, made judge in such a case; I'le give a limbe to bee quitt now; but if shee chuse, I am a criple for this world.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Is it possible? A man and such a beast?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Soe: I must to the shambles.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: What punishment can bee equall to the offence?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Hee lookes with some compunction for his fault, troth, Madame, such an other
night: and trye whether hee'le sleepe againe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mercifull wench; if wee piece againe; it shall bee a good turne in thy way.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: My husband is resolu'd this day for London. It is his humour, or else worse, suspition: there's noe pretence for him to stay behinde.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You have made ill use of your time Sir Francis; I know not how to helpe you; seauen yeares hence you may have such an other opportunitie.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Watch if my husband come not this way, Dorothy, well Sir, though your transgression deserve no pardon, yet I am charitable upon condition.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Any thinge, Madame: this shewes excellent in you. No pennance shall displease, so you absolue me. Bid me to clyme some rocke or piramide, upon whose narrow speare you have advanc'd my peace, and I will reach it, or else fall lost to the world in my contempt.

sp.speaker: Lad
sp.p: You speake gloriously, the condition that assures your pardon, is only this, that you conclude, here, all your loose desires, with a resolve never to prosecute or hope to enjoye me:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Call you this charitie, let me rather loose your pardon, then ever bee thus Divorc'd: binde me never to see you, (and yet that were cruelty) then, charme me to forget that I am man, or have a heart, and you a beautie which your absence can as well make nothinge, as divide from my adoreing
It is not cure but killing to prescribe I never must enioye you, if you have resolu'd death upon me, let it bee when wee like lovers have embrac'd.

sp.speaker: Lad
sp.p: It is not possible.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: nothing in loue can bee impossible to willing mynds. I'le tell you, Madame, Sure the devill has forsworne the flesh, there may bee a plott, I have it. An excellent rare Device, if you but favour it: your husband is immediately for London I must in modesty ride with him; you are left behinde.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: How can that proffit you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What a deale of submission these foolish men trouble us women with, that are more forward to bee frends againe, then they?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I will counterfeit a fall.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: A fall?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I, from my horse, observe me then.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My confederate I hope by this time is at the gate enquiringe for Sir Richard very formally from the old Knight his Master & good Lady: the follow has witt to mannage it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Footman shall pretend himselfe the surgeon to attend me; I'st not rare? stand but to it fate in this and if I faile I will sit downe a convert and renownce all wanton hope hereafter. Deerest Madame if you did meane this honour to me before let not your louinge thoughts freeze in a minute; my genius is a prophet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir Richard, Madame, is cominge this way.

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.p: Shall I hope againe

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: I will not say you shall dispayre.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You blesse me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My businesse is on foote, your Jewell Madame will credit much the cause.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Wee will with draw; and let me know how you, have cast the plott. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir Richard (openinge a letter) & Footman.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: From thy Master? his name?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sir William Litleland.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I doe not know him.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: His name is well known in Lincolneshire neere the Fenns; there were of his family Ancient Gentlemen before the conquest, some say, ever since the flood,

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Little Land?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: But hee has now more land then 3. of the best of the sheere, thank the dutch men that have drunke up al the water.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: They water— drinkers?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Why not, as well as eate dry land? they are lyn'd with butter; Sir; they feare noe dropsies.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.

body.p:
Shee has bin absent these two yeares, the occasion her dislike and disaffection to a Gentleman whome I confesse, I did severely urge her to marry, if shee have liv'd with you, as my late intelligence informs me in the nature of a Servant, which is beneath my wish and her condition, I hope upon this knowledge, you will with consider of her qualittie shee beinge my
only child and heyre to my fortunes, use her like a Gentlewoman: and though my peares have made me unfitt for trauell I doe Intend upon the returne of my daughter, whome I shall receive as a new blessinge from you, to expresse my selfe for your favour

closer.signed: Your trew Frend and Servant WILLIAM LITTELAND.

sp.p: My maid Dorothy A knights daughter & heire? doe you know your younge Mistrisse?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I shall bee happie to see her, with a Letter and token from her Lady Mother.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I pray trust me to deliver it.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I, With all my heart, Sir; you may command.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Thomas, pray entertaine this Footman in the buttery: let him drinke & refresh him selfe and set the cold chine of beefe before him hee has runn hard.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: That will stay his stomack indeede; but claret is his only binder.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sack while you liue after a heate, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Pease you, I'le shew you the way to be drunke. Exit with Footman.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: To my lovinge daughter? may not this bee a trick? Enter Vnderwitt.
By your favour Madame; Captaine, gather you the sence of that Letter, while I peruse this, you know Mistris Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p:
I have had a greate desire to know her,
I confesse, but shee is still like the bottom of the mapp, Terra incognita, I have ben a long time hoveringe about the Magellan straytes but have made no new discoveryes.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Ha! This is no counterfeit; I dare trust my owne Judgment; tis a very rich one I am confirm'd, and I will seale them up againe. My Ladyes Woman Sir William Littelands daughter and heyre? what say you now of Mistresse Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: A great deale better then I did, and yet I have loud her this halfe yeare in a kinde of way, of my conscence, why may not I marry her?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: This Jewell was sent by her Mother to her.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Deare Vncle conceale it till I have talke with her, oh for some witchcraft to make all sure.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I like this well: shee's here.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: I vow, Mistresse Dorothy; if I were immodest, it was the meere impudence of my sack, and not my owne disposition but if you please to accept my loue now by the way of marriage I'le make you satisfaction, like a Gentleman in the point of honour.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: your birth and estate is to high and unequall for me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: What care I for portion or a face, shee that has good eyes, has good— Give me vertue.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You are pleas'd to make your mirth of me.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: By this ruby nay; you shall weare it in the broad eye of the world; doest thinke I jest?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir Richard:—

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: If hee were ten Sir Richards, I am out of my wardship

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How hee flutters in the lyme-bush: it takes rarely. Aside.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: What a necessary thinge were a houshold chapline? Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: So; so; the wench inclynes, I will hasten my jornie that I may appeare with more excuse, when they are married in my absence. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Master Courtwell, Sister and Device.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Come wee are fast enough, and now I have thee, I'le tell the all the fault I finde, thou hast a little two much wit, to bee a wife: it could not bee too nimble for a Mistresse. There is a part of your pennance still behind Device; you would pretend to bee a poet, I'le not disgrace the name to call thee one, but let me have times against wee goe to bed, Two Anagrames that weigh an ownce with coment, and after that, in verse your affidavitt that you doe wish us joye, and I'le discharge you.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Tis time I were at study then.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
About them, your double congie, and depart with silence: now prithee tell me who reported I had wrong'd a Lady? Was it
not thy revenge to make me Angry?

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: It was indeed Now tell me; why at the first approach seem'd you so modest? you have confidence to spare, now.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Troth I came not with any wooinge purpose: only to please my Vnkle, and try thy witt and that converted me. Enter Tho.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Did you see my Master Captaine Vnderwit?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes he's talkinge with a priest and Mistresse Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Her Fathers Footeman is heere, shee is a Knights daughter and heyre, but shee doth not know it.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: I thinke soe?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Where's my Vnkle?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A myle on his way to London, by this time with Sir Richard, I longe to see my Master. Exit.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Wee shall want Companie to dance.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: My Sister.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If you please Madame, you may call me, Brother, wee have ben at, I Iohn take thee Elisabeth, a possett and foure naked thighes in a bed to night, wee'le bid faire earnest for a boy too.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Tis even so Madame; the Priest has done it

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Nay then all joyes attend you; if this had bin knowen, it might have, stay'd Sir Richard, and your Vnkle one day more.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Roome for an other couple.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: In hell, my Master is maried.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: My husband left some letters, and a token was sent you Mistris Dorothy, you did Ill to obscure your selfe so much, you shall not want hereafter all respects that may become you.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.p: Madame I know not what you meane.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Shee will not take it upon her, yet.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: There is the sport Enter Device.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Oh Madame, newes; Ill newes; an Accident which will blast all your mirth, Sir Francis;—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What of him.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Has broake;—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: His neck?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: You guesse very neere it, tis but, his shoulder has sav'd that Joynt; a fall from his horse they saye hath much endangerd him.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: My Vnckle hurt? Exit.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Hee has kept his word; now if hee counterfeyte handsomely.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Monsieur Device, I must entreat a courtesie: you have wit and I will have a Masque to entertaine my new Father in Law Sir William Littleland; Mistris Dorothy now my wife is his only daughter & heyre

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Who has gull'd you thus? I am no Knights daughter.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Give you Joy Captaine

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Shee is still loath to confesse it.

div.stage: Enter Sir Francis; Master Courtwell, Lady, Sister, Sackbury.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If you loue charitie; a bone setter.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Hee counterfeites rarely, where is Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hee rid before, but I sent my Footeman, to tell him my misfortune; oh; Madame.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: This is better then the tooth atch; he carries it excellently.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Aske me no torturinge questions, I desire Madame a little conference with you, I'le thanke the rest if they will with draw.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Lett's leaue him.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Wee'le to my chamber, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: You have a minde to examine the businesse privatly.

sp.speaker: Vnd
sp.p: No, good Captaine you may bee present, come; Thomas, thou shalt bee wittnesse too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: They are gone, you faine most Artificially, let me embrace you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh take heede.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: What's the matter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Tis noe dissembling, Madame; I have had a fall indeede: a dreadfull fall, I feele it, I thinke my horse sawe the devill in some hedge, ere I had rid three furlongs: gaue a start, pitch'd me off his back like a barre and broake a flynt with my shoulder, I thinke; which strooke fire too there was somethinge like it in my eyes; I am punished.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: But is this serious, are you hurt indeede?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Hurt? I have broake my shoulder, feelingly, and I am of opinion when I doe enjoy you, Madame, I shall breake my neck: that will bee the next; I'le take this for a
warninge and will leaue of in time.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: It makes me tremble.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I will bee honest now, and so forgive me, is not the surgeon come yet?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Heaven hath cur'd us both.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am not cur'd yet, oh for the bone setter, if ever I counterfeit againe.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: There is a blessing falne upon my bloud: your only thoughts charme had power to make my thoughts wicked, and your conversion disenchants me: may both our liues be such as heaven may not greeve, to have shewed this bountie.

div.stage: Enter Courtwell and the rest with Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sir Richard; Madame:

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: You may enter now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I doe not like this Stratagem, Sir Francis must not heere practice his court tricks, I will not trust my wifes surgery:
Hee's come; Sir Francis is led out.
How is it noble Sir Francis; best with draw, I'le see him drest my selfe.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Madame and Gentleman; Mistrisse Dorothy will not acknowledge she is a Knights daughter she sweares she knowes no Littleland.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Till it appeare to whome, this Iemm was meant, deafe Madame, bee you treasurer, I confesse I have wealth enough in such a noble husband.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: It shall belonge to thee; be honest Dorothy, and use him well.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: With my best study, Madame;

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Where is this Footeman you talke of?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: He pretended letters to carry two myles off to a Kinsmans of his Masters and returne presently: hee drunke 3. or 4. beere glasses of Sack and hee rune away so lightly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: His reward shall overtake him.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Will you have her; shee'le doe you service, Captaine at a low Country leager or thou Thomas I le give thee a coppihold.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: You have one life to come in that lease yet, I thanke you I am free, and that is Inheritance. For ought I know shee may serve us both.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Come you may persuade her to take it upon her for your creditt, the gullery is yet with in these walls let your shames goe noe further, the wench may prove right; shee may.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: What newes from Sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Wife I hartily aske thy forgivenesse: I had jealous thoughts, but all is right againe.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: I will deserve your confidence.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: No greate danger, his blade bone dislocated: the man has put every thinge in his right place

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Doe you heare Sir Richard, wee are married.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Tis well done t'is to my mynd, send you Joy;

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Come hither Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My Mother dyed, I have it by tradition, soe, as soone as I was borne my Father but no Knight, is now in the Indies a poore Marchant that broake for 20000.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: The ships may come home, ha;

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You had best use me well now wee are married, I will bee sworne you forc'd me to the church and thrise compeld me there to said, I Dorothy— The Parsons oath and mine, for ought I know may make it halfe a rape.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: There is no remedy wee can proue no conspiracy; and because I have bin gull'd my selfe, gett her with childe; my Doe is barren, at birth of hir first baby I'le give thee a hundred peeces.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: That's somewhat yet: when charge coms on, thy hand, a wife can bee but a wife: it shall cost me 500. but I'le make thee a Laay in earnest.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: How is it Sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Surgeon sayes no danger: when you please I may venture Sir to London.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Noe hast now.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Not to night, Sir, wee must have revells, and you salute my bride.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: And myne.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A Knights daughter and heyre.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
May all Joyes thriue upon your Ioues; then you are cozen'd of your Mistresse Monsieur, but your nephew knowes
I have met with my match if not put to the worst.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Come wee loose time.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Preserve your Marriage faith: a full increase of what you wish confirme your happinesse.
